ai-mn104:21.1_0: Ānanda, these six warm-hearted qualities make for fondness and respect, conducing to inclusion, harmony, and unity, without quarreling.
ai-mn104:21.2_0: What are the teachings grouped by six?
ai-mn104:21.3_0: Firstly, a mendicant consistently treats their spiritual companions with bodily kindness, both in public and in private.
ai-mn104:21.4_0: This warm-hearted quality makes for fondness and respect, conducing to inclusion, harmony, and unity, without quarreling.
ai-mn104:21.5_0: Furthermore, a mendicant consistently treats their spiritual companions with verbal kindness ...
ai-mn104:21.6_0: This warm-hearted quality makes for fondness and respect, conducing to inclusion, harmony, and unity, without quarreling.
ai-mn104:21.7_0: Furthermore, a mendicant consistently treats their spiritual companions with mental kindness ...
ai-mn104:21.8_0: This warm-hearted quality makes for fondness and respect, conducing to inclusion, harmony, and unity, without quarreling.
ai-mn104:21.9_0: Furthermore, a mendicant shares without reservation any material possessions they have gained by legitimate means, even the food placed in the alms-bowl, using them in common with their ethical spiritual companions.
ai-mn104:21.10_0: This warm-hearted quality makes for fondness and respect, conducing to inclusion, harmony, and unity, without quarreling.
ai-mn104:21.11_0: Furthermore, a mendicant lives according to the precepts shared with their spiritual companions, both in public and in private. Those precepts are unbroken, impeccable, spotless, and unmarred, liberating, praised by sensible people, not mistaken, and leading to immersion.
ai-mn104:21.12_0: This warm-hearted quality makes for fondness and respect, conducing to inclusion, harmony, and unity, without quarreling.
ai-mn104:21.13_0: Furthermore, a mendicant lives according to the view shared with their spiritual companions, both in public and in private. That view is noble and emancipating, and leads one who practices it to the complete ending of suffering.
